I'm only a first-year CM major so what I know is fairly limited BUT ..

I would recommend CM if you have an interest in both CS and liberal_arts (hence the whole CS + LMC thing). The main difference between CM and CS is that instead of taking a 2nd CS thread, you take an [LMC thread](http://lmcdegree. lmc. gatech. edu/threads/). If there isn't an LMC thread that matches your interests, you might just be better off being a CS major with the Media thread and something else. 

For me, I want to go into UI/UX Design, so I'm doing the People and Interaction Design/Experimental Media threads (a popular path for people who want to go into UI/UX). I love coding but I also love more front-end things like graphic design and interface design. Though there are CS courses on these topics (CS 3750 - User Interface Design), I feel like LMC courses allow you to explore this aspect even more, whereas CS sort of gives you an introduction. 

That[.] not to say you can't do this through a CS major, because I have tons of CS friends who want to go into the same field as me and chose People and Media threads. I just feel like being a CM major lets you learn more specific info about the field without a lot of the unnecessary stuff that[.] in the CS core (like I didn't have to take physics, for example). 

Although, this is just my very-specific, personal case. I know lots of game designers, (music) producers, and animators who are in CM, as well. There[.] probably a ton of other fields I don't know about, too. 

I would also recommend you don't choose CS just because no one knows what "Computational Media" is because I don't want you to pick something for the "name" and just suffer through it when there[.] a another perfectly viable option available. 

If you have any other CM questions, feel free to ask!
